revision.text:
{{ infobox nobility | name = Frederick III, Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg | image = Hessenški deželni grof Friederich III. (sr. 17. st.).jpg | caption = Portrait of Frederick III in the [[National Museum of Slovenia]] | noble family = [[House of Hesse]] | father = [[Frederick II, Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg]] | mother = [[Louise Elisabeth of Courland]] | spouse = [[Elisabeth Dorothea of Hesse-Darmstadt]]
[[Christiane Charlotte of Nassau-Ottweiler]] | birth_date = {{birth_date|1673|5|19|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Cölln]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1746|6|8|1673|5|19|df=yes}} | death_place = [['s-Hertogenbosch]] }} '''Frederick III James of Hesse-Homburg''' (born 19 May 1673 in [[Cölln]]; died: 8 June 1746 in [['s-Hertogenbosch]]) was a Landgrave of [[Hesse-Homburg]] == Life == Frederick III James was the second son of Landgrave [[Frederick II, Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg|Frederick II of Hesse-Homburg]] (1633–1708), the famous ''Prince of Homburg'', from his marriage with [[Louise Elisabeth of Courland|Louise Elisabeth]] (1646–1690), daughter of the Duke [[Jacob Kettler|Jacob of Courland]] (1610–1662). He received a thorough education in the culturally and spiritually progressive atmosphere of the Electoral Court in Berlin, where his father served as commander of the Brandenburg troops,. After his confirmation in 1687, he joined the [[Knight academy]] in [[Wolfenbüttel]]. Later, he joined a [[Cavalry]] Regiment in [[Württemberg]]. In 1690, he was [[Captain (OF-2)|Captain]] in the [[Dutch States Army]]; in 1692, he was [[Colonel]] of the [[Groningen]] cavalry regiment. He kept being promoted: to [[Brigadier]] in 1701, to [[Major General]] in 1704 and after [[Battle of Blenheim]] on 13 August 1704, to [[Lieutenant General]]. He remained in the Dutch service until the [[Peace of Utrecht]], and then took up government in [[Bad Homburg]]. Frederick III could not contribute much to the administration of his territory while he was in Dutch service. Worth mentioning, however, is the foundation in 1721 of the orphanage in Homburg, which still exists as a "Landgraviate Foundation". The archives of the Foundation were transferred to the Bad Homburg city archives in August 2010. Frederick's tolerant religious policies permitted the publication in Homburg of the book {{lang|de|''Ein Geistlicher Würtz-Kräuter und Blumen-Garten oder des Universal-Gesang-Buchs''}} ("A religious herbs-and-flower garden, or the universal song-book") by [[Christoph Schütz]]. After the public debt in [[Hesse-Homburg]] had grown considerably, Frederick was forced by an imperial [[debit commission]] to again take service in Holland in 1738. He was [[governor]] of the Belgian city of [[Liège]], then governor from 1741, governor of [[Breda]]. In 1742, he was promoted to [[General of the Cavalry (Germany)|General of the Cavalry]]. He died in 1746, as governor of 's-Hertogenbosch and was buried in the [[crypt]] of [[Bad Homburg Castle]]. Since none of his children survived him, he was succeeded as the Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg by [[Frederick IV, Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg|Frederick IV]], the son of his younger brother [[Casimir William of Hesse-Homburg|Casimir William]]. == Marriages and Issue == In [[Butzbach]] on 14 February 1700, Frederick III married firstly [[Elisabeth Dorothea of Hesse-Darmstadt]] (Darmstadt, 24 April 1676 - Homburg, 9 September 1721); she was the daughter of [[Louis VI, Landgrave of Hesse-Darmstadt]]. They had nine children:[http://wwperson.informatik.uni-erlangen.de/cgi-bin/l1/LANG=engl/INDEX=I130446 ''Friedrich III. Jacob Landgraf v.Hessen-Homburg'' in: Genealogy Database by Herbert Stoyan] [retrieved 5 October 2014].[http://www.royaltyguide.nl/families/hessen/hessenhomburg.htm Hesse Homburg line in: Royaltyguide.nl] [retrieved 5 October 2014]. #Stillborn daughter (Homburg, 27 November 1700). #Fredericka Dorothea Sophia Ernestine (Groningen, 29 September 1701 - Homburg, 11 March 1704). #Frederick William Louis (Groningen, 1 November 1702 - Groningen, 19 August 1703). #Louise Wilhelmine Eleonore Franziska (Homburg, 2 December 1703 - Homburg, 20 August 1704). #[[Louis Gruno of Hesse-Homburg|Louis John William Gruno, Hereditary Prince of Hesse-Homburg]] (Homburg, 15 January 1705 - Berlin 13 October 1745), Russian [[Field Marshal]], married on 3 February 1738 to Princess [[Anastasia Trubezkaya]] (14 October 1700 - St. Petersburg, 27 November 1755). #[[John Charles of Hesse-Homburg|John Charles William Ernest Louis]] (Homburg, 24 August 1706 - Fellin, 10 May 1728). #Ernestine Louise Dorothea Charlotte (Homburg, 29 January 1707 - Homburg, 19 December 1707). #Stillborn son (Homburg, 17 February 1713). #Frederick Ulrich Louis (Homburg, 2 September 1721 - Homburg, 16 November 1721). In [[Saarbrücken]] on 17 October 1728 Frederick III married secondly [[Christiane Charlotte of Nassau-Ottweiler]] (Ottweiler, 2 September 1685 - Homburg, 6 November 1761), widow of Count [[Charles Louis, Count of Nassau-Saarbrücken|Charles Louis of Nassau-Saarbrücken]]. They had no children. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} == References == * Johann Caspar Bluntschli: [https://books.google.com/books?id=fXEKAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA180&dq=Friedrich+III.+Jakob+Homburg&lr=&hl=de ''Deutsches Staatswörterbuch'', p. 180] * Johann I. von Gerning: [https://books.google.com/books?id=zGwAAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA155&dq=Friedrich+III.+Jakob+Homburg&lr=&hl=de ''Die Lahn- und Main-Gegenden von Embs bis Frankfurt'', p. 155] * Carl Eduard Vehse: [https://books.google.com/books?id=AVgAAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA453&dq=Friedrich+III.+Jakob+Homburg&lr=&hl=de ''Geschichte der deutschen Höfe seit der Reformation'', p. 453] == External links == * [http://www.landstift.de/ Homepage des Kinderheims The Landgraviate Foundation] {{S-start}} {{S-hou|[[House of Hesse]]|19 May|1673|8 Juni|1746}} {{S-bef|before=[[Frederick II, Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg|Frederick II]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[Hesse-Homburg|Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg]]|years=1708–1746}} {{S-aft|after=[[Frederick IV, Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg|Frederick IV]]}} {{S-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Frederick 03 Hesse Homburg}} [[Category:Landgraves of Hesse]] [[Category:House of Hesse-Homburg]] [[Category:1673 births]] [[Category:1746 deaths]] [[Category:17th-century German people]] [[Category:18th-century German people]]
